clusters.title: Trump signs executive order rebranding Pentagon as 'Department of War'
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Renames Pentagon as Department of War

items.title: Trump signs executive order rebranding Pentagon as 'Department of War'
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defence as the "Department of War," reverting to a title it held until after World War II. The switch was signal that the department was "a force to be reckoned with", said Trump after months of complaining that the original name was "woke".
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defence as the "Department of War," reverting to a title it held until after World War II. The switch was signal that the department was "a force to be reckoned with", said Trump after months of complaining that the original name was "woke".

items.title: Trump signs Dept. of War order, announces 2026 G20 will be at Doral
items.standfirst: President Trump on Friday signed an executive order to begin the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War.
items.content: President Trump on Friday signed an executive order to begin the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War.

items.title: Trump Signs Order to Rename Pentagon the Department of War
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defense as the Department of War, calling the move a reversion to a time before America went “woke.” The shift dovetails with Trump’s bid to project a more aggressive posture for the Pentagon by touting “lethality” and an…
items.content: President Donald Trump signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defense as the Department of War, calling the move a reversion to a time before America went “woke.” The shift dovetails with Trump’s bid to project a more aggressive posture for the Pentagon by touting “lethality” and an…

items.title: Behind Trump's order for Department of War name change
items.standfirst: President Trump signed his 200th executive order, seeking to rename the Department of Defense to the Department of War. The move restores the name the agency last held in the 1940s. Charlie D'Agata has more.
items.content: President Trump signed his 200th executive order, seeking to rename the Department of Defense to the Department of War. The move restores the name the agency last held in the 1940s. Charlie D'Agata has more.

items.title: Why the Department of War name is making a comeback
items.standfirst: President Trump began the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War. It's been more than 75 years since that name was used. CBS News' Aaron Navarro has more details.
items.content: President Trump began the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War. It's been more than 75 years since that name was used. CBS News' Aaron Navarro has more details.

items.title: Defense Department Scrambles to Pretend It’s Called the War Department
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said the so-called Department of War branding is to counter the “woke” Department of Defense name.
items.content: President Donald Trump said the so-called Department of War branding is to counter the “woke” Department of Defense name.

items.title: Trump signs executive order renaming Defense to Department of War
items.standfirst: President Trump singed an executive order Friday directing the Department of Defense to use the name Department of War as a "secondary title" — restoring a name it last held in the late 1940s.
items.content: President Trump singed an executive order Friday directing the Department of Defense to use the name Department of War as a "secondary title" — restoring a name it last held in the late 1940s.

items.title: Trump changes the Department of Defense’s name to ‘Department of War’
items.standfirst: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth says the name change signals a more offensive approach for the US military under Trump.
items.content: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth says the name change signals a more offensive approach for the US military under Trump.

items.title: Trump signs executive order rebranding Pentagon as Department of War
items.standfirst: Directive will make Department of War secondary title and is way to get around need for congressional approvalDonald Trump signed an executive order on Friday to rebrand the Department of Defense as the Department of War, a callback to the department’s original name used from 1789 to 1947.The directive will make Department of War the secondary title, and is a way to get around the need for congressional approval to formally rename a federal agency, an administration official said. Continue reading...
items.content: Directive will make Department of War secondary title and is way to get around need for congressional approvalDonald Trump signed an executive order on Friday to rebrand the Department of Defense as the Department of War, a callback to the department’s original name used from 1789 to 1947.The directive will make Department of War the secondary title, and is a way to get around the need for congressional approval to formally rename a federal agency, an administration official said. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin rejects Western security in Ukraine, warning troops would be target
items.standfirst: The Russian leader's refusal comes after 26 countries pledged to deploy troops to Ukraine in the event of a ceasefire.
items.content: The Russian leader's refusal comes after 26 countries pledged to deploy troops to Ukraine in the event of a ceasefire.

items.title: Putin says foreign troops in Ukraine would be legitimate targets
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Friday thousands of foreign troops could be deployed to his country under post-war security guarantees, but Russian leader Vladimir Putin said Moscow would regard them as legitimate targets to attack.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Friday thousands of foreign troops could be deployed to his country under post-war security guarantees, but Russian leader Vladimir Putin said Moscow would regard them as legitimate targets to attack.

items.title: Putin sends grave warning to Ukraine's allies over Western troop deployment
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said any foreign troops operating as part of a peacekeeping force in Ukraine would be considered a "legitimate target" by Moscow.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said any foreign troops operating as part of a peacekeeping force in Ukraine would be considered a "legitimate target" by Moscow.

ai_summary: Trump signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defense to Department of War.
The name change reverts to a title the department held until after World War II.
Trump stated the move signals the department is a force to be reckoned with.
The shift aligns with Trump's goal to project a more aggressive posture.
Former Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta shared his thoughts on the name change.

items.title: British couple killed in Lisbon funicular crash named
items.standfirst: Kayleigh Smith, 36, and William Nelson, 44, among passengers who died when the Elevador da Glória derailed A British couple killed in Lisbon after a funicular streetcar derailed on Wednesday have been named as Kayleigh Smith and William Nelson.Smith, 36, and Nelson, 44, died alongside 14 other people after the Elevador da Glória hurtled down a hill and careered into a building. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.content: Authorities have confirmed three Brits are among 16 people who were killed in Wednesday's accident.

items.title: Lisbon streetcar crash death toll rises to 16, including U.S. citizen, as Portugal observes day of mourning
items.standfirst: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.
items.content: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.

ai_summary: A British couple, Kayleigh Smith and William Nelson, died in the Lisbon crash.
The funicular streetcar derailed on Wednesday, causing the fatalities.
Sixteen people died in the accident, including three British nationals.
A College of Charleston instructor was also among the victims.
Witnesses described the funicular as being out of control before the crash.

items.title: Trump threatens more tariffs after EU fines Google €2.95B
Trump Threatens More Tariffs Against EU After Google Fine
Trump threatens new tariffs over EU's $3.5 billion antitrust fine against Google
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out against the European Union’s $3.47 billion antitrust fine against Google as “unfair” and threatened retaliatory tariffs if the bloc does not reverse the penalty. Trump's rebuke came a day after he hosted tech leaders, including Google’s top executives, at a White House dinner.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out against the European Union’s $3.47 billion antitrust fine against Google as “unfair” and threatened retaliatory tariffs if the bloc does not reverse the penalty. Trump's rebuke came a day after he hosted tech leaders, including Google’s top executives, at a White House dinner.

clusters.title: US immigration agents arrest hundreds at Hyundai plant, South Korea expresses ‘concern’
clusters.neutral_headline: US Immigration Agents Arrest Workers at Hyundai Plant

items.title: US immigration agents arrest hundreds at Hyundai plant, South Korea expresses ‘concern’
items.standfirst: Around 475 workers, mostly South Korean nationals, were arrested during a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raid on a Hyundai plant hailed as "the largest development project" in Georgia. The incident could exacerbate tensions between Washington and Seoul, a key US ally that has been encouraged to increase investments in the US.
items.content: Around 475 workers, mostly South Korean nationals, were arrested during a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raid on a Hyundai plant hailed as "the largest development project" in Georgia. The incident could exacerbate tensions between Washington and Seoul, a key US ally that has been encouraged to increase investments in the US.

items.title: South Korean workers arrested during immigration raid at Hyundai site
items.standfirst: Homeland security officials said they arrested 450 workers who were in the country illegally during a raid at a construction site for a Hyundai plant. Most of the workers are from South Korea. The workers were not Hyundai employees. NBC News’ Priya Sridhar reports.
items.content: Homeland security officials said they arrested 450 workers who were in the country illegally during a raid at a construction site for a Hyundai plant. Most of the workers are from South Korea. The workers were not Hyundai employees. NBC News’ Priya Sridhar reports.

items.title: At least 475 workers detained in major Ice raid at US Hyundai factory
items.standfirst: South Korea alarmed after hundreds of nationals arrested at Georgia work site making batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsHundreds of workers at a factory being built in Georgia to make car batteries for Hyundai and Kia electric vehicles were detained in a huge raid by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) on Thursday that stopped construction.The facility is part of what would be the biggest industrial investment in the state’s history and had been hailed as a huge boost for the economy by Georgia’s Republican governor, Brian Kemp. Continue reading...
items.content: South Korea alarmed after hundreds of nationals arrested at Georgia work site making batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsHundreds of workers at a factory being built in Georgia to make car batteries for Hyundai and Kia electric vehicles were detained in a huge raid by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) on Thursday that stopped construction.The facility is part of what would be the biggest industrial investment in the state’s history and had been hailed as a huge boost for the economy by Georgia’s Republican governor, Brian Kemp. Continue reading...

items.title: ICE raid at Hyundai plant leaves South Korea concerned as 'many' nationals detained
items.standfirst: The Fortune 500 company confirmed the presence of law enforcement at the LG Energy Solution and Hyundai battery joint venture construction site in Ellabell.
items.content: The Fortune 500 company confirmed the presence of law enforcement at the LG Energy Solution and Hyundai battery joint venture construction site in Ellabell.

ai_summary: US immigration agents arrested approximately 475 workers at a Hyundai plant.
The raid targeted a Hyundai-LG battery manufacturing facility in Georgia.
Most of the arrested workers were South Korean nationals.
The South Korean government expressed concern over the raid.
The raid is the largest single-site operation by ICE to date.

clusters.title: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of protections for Venezuelans and Haitians
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of protections for Venezuelans and Haitians

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of protections for Venezuelans and Haitians
items.standfirst: A federal judge on Friday blocked the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections for more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela who live in the United States.
items.content: A federal judge on Friday blocked the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections for more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela who live in the United States.(Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of legal protections for 1.1M Venezuelans and Haitians
Judge blocks Trump from ending TPS for Venezuelans and Haitians
items.standfirst: A federal judge in California ruled that the Trump administration's attempt to end the Temporary Protected Status program for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan and Haitian migrants was unlawful. Camilo Montoya-Galvez explains.
items.content: A federal judge in California ruled that the Trump administration's attempt to end the Temporary Protected Status program for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan and Haitian migrants was unlawful. Camilo Montoya-Galvez explains.

items.title: Judge rules against Trump's attempt to end protections for Venezuelans, Haitians
items.standfirst: Judge Edward Chen ruled against the Trump administration in a challenge to its effort to end the Temporary Protected Status program for roughly 1 million Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.
items.content: Judge Edward Chen ruled against the Trump administration in a challenge to its effort to end the Temporary Protected Status program for roughly 1 million Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.

items.title: Judge blocks ending of legal protections for 1m Venezuelans and Haitians in US
items.standfirst: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...
items.content: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A federal judge blocked the Trump administration's action.
The action would have ended protections for Venezuelans and Haitians.
The judge ruled the attempt to end TPS was unlawful.
The ruling impacts roughly 1 million Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.
The ruling allows Venezuelans to stay and work in the United States.

Anthropic's $1.5-billion settlement signals new era for AI and artists
items.standfirst: It's the largest known settlement in a U.S. copyright infringement case.
items.content: It's the largest known settlement in a U.S. copyright infringement case.

items.title: Anthropic to pay authors $1.5B to settle lawsuit over pirated chatbot training material
items.standfirst: The artificial intelligence company Anthropic has agreed to pay authors $3,000 per book in a landmark settlement over pirated chatbot training material.
items.content: The artificial intelligence company Anthropic has agreed to pay authors $3,000 per book in a landmark settlement over pirated chatbot training material.(Image credit: Richard Drew)

items.title: Anthropic Agrees to Pay Authors at Least $1.5 Billion in AI Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.
items.content: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.

items.title: Anthropic Reaches $1.5 Billion Author Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.
items.content: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.

ai_summary: Anthropic agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit.
Authors accused Anthropic of using their books without permission.
The lawsuit alleged the books were used to train its Claude AI.
Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work.
The settlement is the largest known in a U.S. copyright case.

clusters.title: UK’s Starmer overhauls his government after deputy prime minister resigns over tax error

items.title: UK’s Starmer overhauls his government after deputy prime minister resigns over tax error
items.standfirst: Prime Minister Keir Starmer shook up his Cabinet Friday after his top deputy stepped down over a tax error on a home purchase, leaving a big hole in the center-left Labour government.
items.content: Prime Minister Keir Starmer shook up his Cabinet Friday after his top deputy stepped down over a tax error on a home purchase, leaving a big hole in the center-left Labour government.

items.title: UK's Starmer overhauls his cabinet after deputy PM resigns amid tax scandal
items.standfirst: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Friday undertook the first major reshuffle of his cabinet since coming to power in July 2024, after deputy premier Angela Rayner resigned following a tax scandal. Her departure comes as Starmer's Labour government has been struggling to achieve its main goal of firing up Britain's economy.
items.content: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Friday undertook the first major reshuffle of his cabinet since coming to power in July 2024, after deputy premier Angela Rayner resigned following a tax scandal. Her departure comes as Starmer's Labour government has been struggling to achieve its main goal of firing up Britain's economy.

items.content: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.

ai_summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer reshuffled his cabinet on Friday.
The reshuffle followed the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner.
Rayner resigned due to a tax error on a home purchase.
The Labour government is struggling to improve Britain's economy.
The reshuffle is the first major one since Starmer took office.

items.title: US added just 22,000 jobs in August, continuing slowdown amid Trump tariffs
items.standfirst: Latest report also contained more bad news – the US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to latest surveyThe US jobs market stalled over the summer, adding just 22,000 jobs in August and continuing a slowdown in the labor market as businesses adjusted to disruptions caused by tariffs.The latest jobs report also contained more bad news. The US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to the latest survey, the first time it went into the negative since December 2020.Federal employment dropped 15,000 jobs in August, totaling 97,000 jobs lost since January.Manufacturing jobs went down by 12,000 in August and have tumbled 78,000 for the year.The racial unemployment gap widened in August. Black Americans are seeing an unemployment rate of 7.5%, compared to 6.1% last August. The unemployment rate for White Americans is 3.7% Continue reading...
items.content: Latest report also contained more bad news – the US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to latest surveyThe US jobs market stalled over the summer, adding just 22,000 jobs in August and continuing a slowdown in the labor market as businesses adjusted to disruptions caused by tariffs.The latest jobs report also contained more bad news. The US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to the latest survey, the first time it went into the negative since December 2020.Federal employment dropped 15,000 jobs in August, totaling 97,000 jobs lost since January.Manufacturing jobs went down by 12,000 in August and have tumbled 78,000 for the year.The racial unemployment gap widened in August. Black Americans are seeing an unemployment rate of 7.5%, compared to 6.1% last August. The unemployment rate for White Americans is 3.7% Continue reading...

items.title: 'Tensions between the US and Venezuela continue to play out at sea'
items.standfirst: Tensions between the US and Venezuela continue to play out at sea, with the US accusing two Venezuelan F-16 fighter jets of flying over a US navy ship in international waters. The Department of Defence called the move "highly provocative" and an attempt to interfere with counter narcotics operations. Earlier this week, the US killed 11 people in a military strike against a suspected drug vessel. Click on this report by Camille Knight for more.
items.content: Tensions between the US and Venezuela continue to play out at sea, with the US accusing two Venezuelan F-16 fighter jets of flying over a US navy ship in international waters. The Department of Defence called the move "highly provocative" and an attempt to interfere with counter narcotics operations. Earlier this week, the US killed 11 people in a military strike against a suspected drug vessel. Click on this report by Camille Knight for more.

items.title: What's behind escalation in US war on drug cartels?
items.standfirst: The Pentagon said two Venezuelan military planes flew near a US Navy vessel in international waters Thursday in a "highly provocative" move that marked a new escalation in the standoff over Washington's Caribbean deployment. It comes after US forces blew up an alleged drug boat in the Caribbean, killing 11 people. France 24's Kethevane Gorjestani takes a look at what is behind the stepping up of Washington's war on drug cartels in the region.
items.content: The Pentagon said two Venezuelan military planes flew near a US Navy vessel in international waters Thursday in a "highly provocative" move that marked a new escalation in the standoff over Washington's Caribbean deployment. It comes after US forces blew up an alleged drug boat in the Caribbean, killing 11 people. France 24's Kethevane Gorjestani takes a look at what is behind the stepping up of Washington's war on drug cartels in the region.
